title: So, uhhh, why'd it take me 6-7 hours straight just to do this?

body:
Because it's 129 lines of javascript, setting up a github project, and testing?  Yeah, a day sounds about right.   

Project setup all by itself can take a couple days depending on what you're doing.   And uuuuugh, javascript. 

Relax, this isn't a crazy time-frame. Were you expecting to hack the gibson in real-time while bullets fly?
body_html:
Because it's 129 lines of javascript, setting up a github project, and testing? Yeah, a day sounds about right.

Project setup all by itself can take a couple days depending on what you're doing. And uuuuugh, javascript.

Relax, this isn't a crazy time-frame. Were you expecting to hack the gibson in real-time while bullets fly?

post.title: So, uhhh, why'd it take me 6-7 hours straight just to do this?

author.bio:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.
author.bio_html:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
Are you sure about that? 6-7 hours is about the same timeframe most people can write a mildly complex algorithm, *in js* (even if it's not their main language!), and have it mostly working. Here are a few examples, note how the time between commits is only a few hours, even if they are long and/or complex:

https://github.com/Foxite/suguru (this commit in particular: https://github.com/Foxite/suguru/commit/07c8964f557a76cc47a10f43415655057e3e5111)

https://github.com/Foxite/picross

https://github.com/GingkathFox/esiJS

https://github.com/GingkathFox/EveShopper

https://github.com/GingkathFox/Node-Browser

And it also happens in languages other than JS:

https://github.com/Foxite/RepDecay

https://github.com/Foxite/ImageSetCompression

https://github.com/Foxite/YoutubeDL

https://github.com/Foxite/PatreonDownloader

https://github.com/Foxite/roosterbot

https://gitlab.com/foxite/someforum

https://github.com/justcool393/BotTerminator

https://github.com/justcool393/SnapshillBot

https://github.com/jakemayeux/pointandclick

I don't see anyone else taking 3-4 hours making a `for` loop through DOM elements work correctly.
body_html:
Are you sure about that? 6-7 hours is about the same timeframe most people can write a mildly complex algorithm, in js (even if it's not their main language!), and have it mostly working. Here are a few examples, note how the time between commits is only a few hours, even if they are long and/or complex:

https://github.com/GingkathFox/esiJS

https://github.com/GingkathFox/EveShopper

https://github.com/GingkathFox/Node-Browser

And it also happens in languages other than JS:

https://github.com/Foxite/RepDecay

https://github.com/Foxite/ImageSetCompression

https://github.com/Foxite/YoutubeDL

https://github.com/Foxite/PatreonDownloader

https://github.com/Foxite/roosterbot

https://gitlab.com/foxite/someforum

https://github.com/justcool393/BotTerminator

https://github.com/justcool393/SnapshillBot

I don't see anyone else taking 3-4 hours making a for loop through DOM elements work correctly.

body:
> How much time do you spend looking up other people's github projects?

Too much, but I'm looking for ways to try and improve. Unfortunately they seem to be doing things no differently than me!

I spent about 6 hours setting up 3 for loops for DOM elements. However I don't see how taking 7 hours to set up a very simple project is normal, seeing as it takes everyone else 1-4 hours for much more advanced projects (they're not exactly super complex, but in comparison to something that just hides ruqqus posts they're more advanced).
body_html:
How much time do you spend looking up other people's github projects?

I spent about 6 hours setting up 3 for loops for DOM elements. However I don't see how taking 7 hours to set up a very simple project is normal, seeing as it takes everyone else 1-4 hours for much more advanced projects (they're not exactly super complex, but in comparison to something that just hides ruqqus posts they're more advanced).

body:
The time between that commit and the last one was only a day. However that's taking into account how much of that time they actually spent on the commit, because their others are much closer together.

I also have talked to many of them and can confirm that they usually do build the "framework" of these projects from scratch in just a few hours.

The time between that commit and the last one was only a day. However that's taking into account how much of that time they actually spent on the commit, because their others are much closer together.

body: JS is indeed bad, but if everyone can do it then why can't I? Most people are about as good in JS as a secondary language as I am in my main, and they are even better at their main. I have the same amount of practice and experience, and it's frustrating taking so long to get anything accomplished. And now seeing that no one else has those problems makes it even worse.
body_html: JS is indeed bad, but if everyone can do it then why can't I? Most people are about as good in JS as a secondary language as I am in my main, and they are even better at their main. I have the same amount of practice and experience, and it's frustrating taking so long to get anything accomplished. And now seeing that no one else has those problems makes it even worse.

post.title: So, uhhh, why'd it take me 6-7 hours straight just to do this?

body:
> I'm looking for ways to try and improve

The only way to improve at programming is:

1. Write something
2. Being stuck and learning a bit to go further
3. Not quitting
4. Goto 1

post.title: So, uhhh, why'd it take me 6-7 hours straight just to do this?

body:
Don't you agree that your method of learning is obviously bad if talking and watching others do not improve yourself? (after all, talking and watching all the time without doing anything never worked for anybody).

Could there be another solution to your problem? Like stopping looking at everyone that is not you and work instead? It's the solution that works for everybody, why don't you try it?
